awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: How do interactions of transport and stoichiometry maximize stream nutrient retention?
awd_abstract_narration:
There is considerable exchange of water and solutes among four compartments of streams: the fast moving part of the stream channel, in-channel storage zones, and shallow and deep sediments zones. Exchanges of water between these compartments promote dissolved nutrient reactions and removal.  The team hypothesizes that nutrient reaction in streams is controlled by not only hydrologic transport, but also stoichiometry of nutrients (ratio of C:N:P).  The team will test their hypotheses by conducting field data collection and stream solute injections at three contrasting Critical Zone Observatory (CZO) sites (Boulder Creek, a rocky mountain setting in Colorado; Catalina-Jemez, a low nutrient setting in New Mexico; and an agricultural landscape in Iowa). Across these three sites there is substantial variability in geology, hydrology, and background nutrient concentrations (and therefore nutrient limitations). The project will engage multiple graduate students with an emphasis on diversity. The team will also organize a workshop to promote and stimulate interaction and exchange of ideas and knowledge among the principal players in the stream restoration field, particularly young scientists and practitioners, stream restoration companies and local environmental agencies.


The exchange of water and solutes among  the river and its hyporheic zones result in a net reaction and removal on nutrients from the stream.  Nutrient reaction and removal (carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorous) in streams is limited by not only the biomass available to take up nutrients, but is also  stoichiometrically limited by the specific reaction. This project will work with the hypothesis that: (1) nutrient retention in streams is controlled by not only hydrologic transport, but also stoichiometry of nutrients (ratio of C:N:P); (2) each compartment of a stream (main channel, surface storage, shallow/deep hyporheic) has a different optimal stoichiometric need (i.e., C:N:P); and (3) depletion of dissolved oxygen from aerobic metabolism is a first-order control that causes a threshold change in the stoichiometric demand of C, N, and P as a compartment becomes anoxic and biogeochemical processes change. The concepts will be tested by conducting field data collection and stream solute injections at three contrasting Critical Zone Observatory (CZO) sites across variable hydrologic conditions at each site to test over a range of hydrologic transport conditions. The team will deploy a suite of methods including electrical resistivity imaging, nutrient tracer injections based on stoichiometric tradeoffs, the Tracer Additions for Spiraling Curve Characterization (TASCC method), application of the "smart" tracer resazurin in streams and use of shallow (MINIPOINT samplers) and deep (wells) hyporheic flow paths. Nutrient tracer injections are designed to specifically decipher stoichiometric controls on nutrient retention in each of the four compartments of the streams.  The broader impacts will be communicated in a workshop setting that identifies reciprocal needs from academic research and restoration programs seeking to approach stream restoration projects more holistically.

por.por_cntn:
The primary objective of this project was to understand how nutrient retention in streams is controlled by hydrologic transport and stoichiometry of nutrients (ratio of C:N:P). We tested our hypotheses at two sites with substantial variability in geology, hydrology, and background nutrient concentrations. We used electrical resistivity imaging, nutrient tracer injections based on stoichiometric tradeoffs, the Tracer Additions for Spiraling Curve Characterization (TASCC method), application of the "smart" tracer resazurin in streams. 

e have published five peer-reviewed articles. In Knapp et al. (2018), we provided a summary of how resazurin can be used from the microbial to the watershed scale, and discussed its advantages and limitations. We provided a detailed manual for its application and codes for the analysis of their transport. In Dallan et al. (2019), we tackled a nonideality eported in previous hydrologic studies, i.e., that dilution‐corrected masses of resazurin and its transformation product, resorufin, were smaller than the mass of resazurin injected. We used laboratory experiments with microbes to quantify mass balances under conditions that removed other suspected causes of incomplete recovery in field experiments, i.e., sorption to sediments and photodecay. We found that the lack of mass recovery in field studies is likely associated with physical or chemical mechanisms rather than biological interactions with the tracer system. 

We worked on developing new techniques to improve tracer injections in the field. In Gonzalez-Pinzon et al. (2019), we introduced The Integrator, a novel technique that simplifies sample collection in sites that are: 1) difficult to access, 2) large and thus intractable or highly heterogeneous, and 3) highly instrumented otherwise but where a more holistic, mechanistic understanding may be gained by monitoring one or more currently untracked elements. In Gonzalez-Pinzon et al. (2022), we implemented a dynamic Excel Workbook to 1) help users decide how much tracer mass should be added to reduce known issues associated with breakthrough curve tail truncation, and 2) generate tables and graphs that can be used to plan the deployment of resources. Our Tracer Injection Planning Tool, TIPT, handles instantaneous and continuous tracer injections and assumes steady-state and uniform flow conditions, as well as first-order decay or production. TIPT is a versatile, user-friendly, and graphical tool that can help design tracer injections that are more easily replicated within and across sites. Thus, TIPT contributes directly to advancing Integrated, Coordinated, Open, and Networked (ICON) principles. Similarly, TIPT can help generate datasets that more closely follow Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable (FAIR) principles. We demonstrated the use of TIPT through two case studies featuring 1) a continuous injection in a 2nd order stream and 2) an instantaneous injection in a 7th order stream.

In the final products from our work, our collaborative team published in Emanuelson et al. (2021) results from conservative stream tracer injections from our study sites in Colorado and Iowa addressing: 1) How does solute transport vary between streams with differing morphologies? and 2) How does solute transport at each stream site change as a function of discharge? In-stream tracer time series data were used to quantify solute attenuation in surface and subsurface transient storage zones. There was a broad range of transport mechanisms and evidence of substantial exchange with both surface and hyporheic transient storage in the stream in Colorado. Conversely, there was a narrow range of solute transport behavior across flows and predominantly surface transient storage at all measured discharge conditions in the agricultural stream in Iowa. These results demonstrate how channel simplification inhibits available solute transport mechanisms across varying discharge conditions. We recently submitted an article summarizing results from experiments in Colorado from two rounds of nutrient experiments, each consisting of four sets of continuous injections of Cl- as a conservative tracer, resazurin as a proxy for aerobic respiration, and one of the following nutrient treatments: a) N, b) N+C, c) N+P, and d) C+N+P. We found that as discharge changed significantly between rounds and across stoichiometric treatments, transient storage mainly occurred in side pools along the main channel and was proportional to discharge, and microbial respiration remained similar between rounds and across stoichiometric treatments. Together, our results indicate that residence time alone could be a weak predictor of stream respiration due to the relevance of local and dynamic variations in stoichiometric conditions.

While doing our research, we trained multiple graduate students and published with them (i.e., Jancoba Dorley, Joel Singley, and Karin Emanuelson). We also trained multiple undergraduate students and offered them unique opportunities to participate in laboratory and field experiments. Our students presented their research outcomes in multiple local, regional, and national conferences and attended workshops on career development. Finally, we produced three high-quality videos describing day-to-day and big picture perspectives on the use of tracer injections, electrical resistivity methods, and the use of smart tracers. These videos were professionally filmed and translated to Spanish and Cantonese.
